text: hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with buckwheat pancakes that's
right don't let the name fool you these
contain neither buck nor wheat which is
of course great news for our gluten-free
friends and while did take a few days to
get the formula just right these really
did end up coming out quite well so
let's go ahead and get started with the
main ingredient a buckwheat flour and
there it is and believe it or not this
is made by grinding the seeds of a plant
related to rhubarb so not only is this
wheat free it's actually grain free and
what we'll do is we'll go ahead and add
the rest of the dry ingredients to this
bowl and that's gonna include a little
bit of sugar a little pinch of salt of
course we're also gonna need some baking
powder and baking soda as well and once
we have all that together we'll take a
whisk and we'll give this a good mix in
for about a minute to kind of mix
everything together you can also sift
this if you want but if you give it a
good whisk in it pretty much does the
same thing and then once our dry
ingredients are set we can grab another
bowl and mix up our wet ingredients
which is going to start with one large
egg we're also gonna want a little hint
of vanilla and then last but not least
some buttermilk
and yes you can use regular milk for
this but the buttermilk an addition to
being low-fat is gonna add some extra
flavor a little bit of Tang eNOS it's
also gonna react with the baking soda in
our dry mix which is gonna create
bubbles that lightens the texture and
we'll go ahead and give that a mix with
a whisk and once that set we'll simply
pour our dry ingredients into our wet
mix and we'll take our whisk and mix
that up to form a fairly thick but still
very portable batter and by the way one
of the advantages of this being gluten
free is that you really don't have to
worry about over mixing this all right
traditional pancake batters will get
tough if you over mix them because of
the proteins in the flour but here we
don't have to worry about that of course
having said that continuing to mix
something that's already mixed is kind
of crazy so we certainly don't wanna
waste time but the point is you don't
have to worry about it mix it up until
it's smooth and looks like this and
you're done and then what we want to do
is let this sit for about five or ten
minutes before we make our pancakes
alrights gonna give all those
ingredients a little time to react with
each other and you can already see we
have lots of bubbles forming so that's
good so like I said we'll let it sit
there about five or ten minutes before
heading over to the stove to cook these
in a nice hot cast-iron skillet or
griddle or whatever you use for your
pancakes
so I usually preheat my pan on
medium-high heat and then before the
batter goes in I like this
Marit with a little bit of butter and
once that's been buttered up it's time
to batter down so I'm gonna ladle my
mixture in to make three pancakes and by
the way if you're wondering why this was
so messy it's cuz I don't want to make a
shadow so I'm reaching up and over the
camera pouring this stuff in from like
three feet away so considering that I
did a pretty good job but anyway we'll
ladle in our batter and by the way once
your batters in the pan you could
probably back your heat down to medium
for the rest of the cooking especially
if you're using cast iron that stores a
lot of heat and yes of course those
microscopic little drops bothered me so
I removed those so I wouldn't go crazy
and all we need to do is cook these for
a few minutes until a couple things
happen first we need to see bubbles
coming up from the bottom bursting
through the top which you can clearly
see here and also the batter around the
edge is gonna start looking kind of dry
and once you do see those two things
you're ready to flip so we'll flip those
over we'll give that second side about a
minute or so and at that point your
buckwheat pancakes are ready to plate up
and by the way I really think these
would work with pretty much anything
people include with regular pancakes you
know stuff like nuts blueberries bananas
etc pretty much anything except
chocolate chips I'm sorry but chocolate
chip pancakes or an abomination but
anyway that's up to you
you are the alfalfa of your buckwheat so
you'll have to decide what to serve with
these little rascals but I'm gonna go
pretty traditional I'm gonna do a little
bit of melted butter over the top and
quite possibly a little in between the
pancakes when the camera was off and
please promise me you're gonna use real
butter I mean why would you make
something this gorgeous and delicious
and nutritious and then desecrate it
with margarine just makes no sense and
then you know what's coming after the
butter a nice generous drizzle of maple
syrup and finally my buckwheat pancakes
are ready for the four check it out for
something that's supposed to be good for
you these don't look too bad so let's
tear right in and despite doing this
recipe with 100% buckwheat flour these
were surprisingly light and tender just
a really Pleasant texture and really not
that heavy at all and as far as the
taste goes yes buckwheat definitely has
a nuttier earthier more pronounced
flavor then a regular white flour does
but I really do think you're gonna enjoy
it and it's funny one of the knocks you
hear about buckwheat pancakes is that
the inside really doesn't have an
attractive color apparently a lot of
people just aren't into dingy grayish
brown food but you know what I disagree
I think these are absolutely gorgeous I
mean something doesn't necessarily have
to be pretty to be beautiful that's
something I learned along
i'ma go from a Christina Aguilera video
but anyway that's it
buckwheat pancakes easy to make
gluten-free and very nutritious and of
course none of that would matter unless
these were really delicious which they
are which is why I hope you give these a
try very soon okay so head over to food
wishes calm for all the ingredient
amounts and more info as usual and as
always enjoy
